intro: Polygala vulgaris var. floribunda, commonly known as the common milkvetch, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in dense, spike-like clusters, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, ovate to lanceolate, and often have a slightly hairy surface. The plant is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in grasslands and along roadsides.
